<text><loc_59><loc_69><loc_268><loc_74>Description: This event sponsored by ECPM aims to:</text>
<unordered_list><list_item><loc_59><loc_77><loc_438><loc_99>- Present a comparative analysis of the key steps that led to abolition (integration of international law, national legislation reform, ...) in the member states of the Organization of the Islamic Conference;</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_102><loc_366><loc_107>- To inform on the role played by different actors in these abolition processes;</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_110><loc_405><loc_124>- To present a comparative position of the OIC Member States vis-à-vis the international instruments;</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_127><loc_316><loc_132>- To give an overview of the situation of the States in moratorium.</list_item>
</unordered_list>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_143><loc_102><loc_149>Speakers:</section_header_level_1>
<unordered_list><list_item><loc_59><loc_151><loc_319><loc_157>- Moderator: Julia Bourbon Fernandez, MONA ECPM Coordinator</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_160><loc_275><loc_165>- Naël George, author of the study published by ECPM</list_item>

<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_103><loc_433><loc_117>Saturday 19 May 8:00-9:30 GMT+2 - 14:00-15:30 (GMT+8): Anti- Death Penalty Asia Youth Forum</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_127><loc_338><loc_133>Description: Objectives of the event sponsored by ADPAN and TAEDP</text>
<unordered_list><list_item><loc_59><loc_136><loc_373><loc_141>- To have a general idea about the recent situation of the death penalty in Asia;</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_144><loc_437><loc_150>- To have a closer look at the latest development of the abolition movement in certain countries;</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_152><loc_342><loc_158>- To exchange the experience and strategies against the death penalty;</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_160><loc_377><loc_166>- To encourage the young activists and to build solidarity among the movement;</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_169><loc_317><loc_174>- To serve as a warm-up event for the next Asia youth workshop.</list_item>
</unordered_list>
<text><loc_59><loc_185><loc_426><loc_191>Facilitator: Dobby CHEW, Executive Coordinator, Anti-Death Penalty Asia Network (ADPAN)</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_193><loc_102><loc_199>Speakers:</section_header_level_1>
<unordered_list><list_item><loc_59><loc_202><loc_217><loc_207>- Malaysia, Eugene How, Misi Solidariti,</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_210><loc_174><loc_215>- Taiwan, Lihan Luo, TAEDP</list_item>
<list_item><loc_59><loc_218><loc_169><loc_224>- India, Ashna Devaprasad</list_item>
</unordered_list>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_235><loc_118><loc_240>Concept Note</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_243><loc_436><loc_257>This event is an inspiration and a continuous effort from the previous Abolitionist Asia Workshop (AAW) held respectively in Taipei in 2013, 2014 in Kuala Lumpur and 2016 in Taipei.</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_268><loc_440><loc_347>More than 20 self-funded activists participated in the first workshop in 2013 and came up with a joint action of delivering a letter demanding ending the death penalty on behalf of the participants to the respective consulates / embassies, such as Thai, Singaporean, Chinese, in our own countries. The topics of the 5-day workshop ranged from case work/ case studies, legal assistance, testimonies from the death row inmates' family, political lobbying, media work and public education, and a field trip to the court, and of course solidarity dinner and fun. The next year, a 3-day workshop was hosted by the KL & Selangor Chinese Assembly Hall in Kuala Lumpur. Two years later in 2016, the 3rd workshop was held again in Taipei and we had more activists from China to join us. The three AAW have built a foundation of cooperation and support even though people came and went through the years.</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_358><loc_437><loc_372>With the call for side events to the WCADP GA, TAEDP partners with ADPAN to jointly organize the Anti- Death Penalty Asia Youth Forum. We hope to invite young activists as speakers from a</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_375><loc_431><loc_405>few target countries to give briefings on their current situation and their strategies/ campaigns. The speakers can also share their personal reflections on the anti-death penalty campaign. This event can serve as a get-together for ADPAN members and friends, as well as a warm-up event for the upcoming Asia workshop organized by TAEDP in 2022.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_416><loc_92><loc_422>Format:</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_424><loc_440><loc_455>One facilitator and a maximum number of 5 speakers. English will be the main language used. Each speaker will speak for 10 minutes giving a brief introduction to the death penalty situation in her/his country and sharing her/his organizational and/or personal reflections. There will be 30 minutes for Questions and Answers.</text>
</doctag>
What is the main topic of the document?
The main topic of the document is the FDA's Strategy for the Safety of Imported Food.
When was the memorandum dated?
The memorandum is dated March 14, 2019.
How many guiding principles has the FDA established for its imported food safety strategy?
The FDA has established seven guiding principles for its imported food safety strategy.
According to the FDA, what is the first priority of the imported food safety strategy?
According to the FDA, protecting public health is the first priority of the imported food safety strategy.
What is the Voluntary Qualified Importer Program (VQIP)?

The Voluntary Qualified Importer Program (VQIP) aims to incentivize importers to use verified suppliers of safe food by strengthening the capacity of foreign suppliers to produce safe food and increasing awareness of food safety requirements and training.
What are the four food safety goals outlined by the FDA's Strategy for the Safety of Imported Food?

The four food safety goals outlined by the FDA's Strategy for the Safety of Imported Food are preventing food safety problems in the foreign supply chain prior to entry, effectively detecting and refusing entry of unsafe foods at the border, rapidly responding to unsafe imported food, and developing and publishing metrics to monitor FDA progress.
What is the strategy mentioned in the text to ensure importer use of verified foreign suppliers?
The strategy mentioned in the text to ensure importer use of verified foreign suppliers is the implementation of the Foreign Supplier Verification Programs (FSVP) regulation.
How does the FDA plan to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of imported food safety recalls?

The FDA plans to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of imported food safety recalls by using information-sharing opportunities with regulatory counterparts with strong food safety systems and exercising its mandatory recall authority granted by FSMA when appropriate.
What additional tool under FSMA does the FDA plan to use to prevent entry of unsafe foods?
The FDA plans to strategically use import certifications, which is one of the new tools under FSMA, to prevent entry of unsafe foods.
What is the overarching fourth goal of the FDA's imported food safety strategy?
The overarching fourth goal of the FDA's imported food safety strategy is to create an effective and efficient food import program, with metrics to measure progress.
What is the FDA's long-term plan for a comprehensive global inventory of food facilities and farms?

The FDA's long-term plan for a comprehensive global inventory of food facilities and farms is to allow FDA to assess the cumulative oversight applied to the imported food inventory and assist in building prevention-based systems.

<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_107><loc_132><loc_114>MEMORANDUM</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_132><loc_85><loc_138>From :</text>
<text><loc_94><loc_132><loc_189><loc_163>Joseph A. Levitt Maile Gradison Hermida Elizabeth Barr Fawell Mary B. Lancaster</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_174><loc_82><loc_180>Date :</text>
<text><loc_94><loc_174><loc_156><loc_180>March 14, 2019</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_191><loc_323><loc_197>Re : FDA Releases Strategy for the Safety of Imported Food</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_208><loc_441><loc_267>The U.S. Food and Drug Administration (FDA) recently released the 'FDA Strategy for the Safety of Imported Food' (the Strategy), which outlines the agency's approach to ensuring the safety of the ever-rising volume of imported foods. 1/  The Strategy sets out four food safety goals: 1) preventing food safety problems in the foreign supply chain prior to entry; 2) detecting and refusing entry of unsafe foods at the border; 3) quickly responding to unsafe imported food; and 4) developing and publishing metrics to monitor FDA progress.  This memorandum provides an overview of the agency's strategy, explains the guiding principles behind this strategy, and summarizes the methods the agency plans to use to accomplish its four goals.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_276><loc_194><loc_282>Strategy and Guiding Principles</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_291><loc_443><loc_320>The U.S. imports about 15 percent of its overall food supply - 32 percent of fresh vegetables, 55 percent of fresh fruit, and 94 percent of seafood - from more than 200 countries or territories representing about 125,000 international food facilities and farms.  The same U.S. food safety requirements apply to all food consumed in the United States, regardless of where it was produced.</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_330><loc_443><loc_381>FDA has developed what it calls 'a multilayered safety net' for imported food, specifying distinct roles for manufacturers, importers, third-party auditors, foreign regulatory bodies, FDA, and other stakeholders.  FDA aims to use the new requirements under the FDA Food Safety Modernization Act (FSMA) regulations to collect and analyze information from these sources to form a more complete picture of the risk of imported food.  The agency also plans to use data analysis to allocate resources in a more targeted way, identifying areas of greater risk where supplemental training or focused outreach efforts can be most beneficial.</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_391><loc_270><loc_397>FDA identifies seven guiding principles for its strategy:</text>
<unordered_list><list_item><loc_74><loc_406><loc_252><loc_412>1. Protecting public health is the first priority.</list_item>
</unordered_list>
<footnote><loc_59><loc_433><loc_363><loc_439>1/ FDA Strategy for the Safety of Imported Food (Mar. 2019), available at:</footnote>
<text><loc_59><loc_441><loc_440><loc_447>https://www.fda.gov/downloads/Food/GuidanceRegulation/ImportsExports/Importing/UCM631864.pd</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_448><loc_68><loc_454>f.</text>
<page_footer><loc_244><loc_463><loc_258><loc_468>- 1 -</page_footer>
<text><loc_353><loc_46><loc_431><loc_83>Hogan Lovells US LLP Columbia Square 555 Thirteenth Street, NW Washington, DC 20004 T  +1 202 637 5600 F  +1 202 637 5910</text>
<text><loc_353><loc_85><loc_422><loc_89>www.hoganlovells.com</text>
<unordered_list><page_break>
<list_item><loc_74><loc_47><loc_393><loc_53>2. Partnering with others to build prevention-based systems is the key to success.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_74><loc_62><loc_443><loc_68>3. Maintaining scientific expertise and innovation as the foundations of FDA's food safety work.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_74><loc_77><loc_364><loc_83>4. Sustaining a level playing field for domestic and foreign food producers.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_74><loc_92><loc_419><loc_106>5. Allocating resources according to risk is the most effective method for protecting public health, and data analytics is the key to prioritizing according to risk.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_74><loc_115><loc_349><loc_121>6. Requiring measurement and ongoing refinement to ensure success.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_74><loc_130><loc_258><loc_136>7. Establishing transparency as the standard.</list_item>
</unordered_list>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_145><loc_173><loc_151>FDA's Goals and Objectives</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_161><loc_439><loc_205>FDA's imported food safety goals fall into three categories: (1) preventing food safety problems in the foreign supply chain prior to entry into the United States, (2) effectively detecting and refusing entry of unsafe foods at the border, and (3) rapidly responding when FDA learns of unsafe imported foods.  An overarching fourth goal is to create an effective and efficient food import program, with metrics to measure progress.  The strategy outlines several methods the agency plans to use to accomplish these goals including strategies for each objective, as summarized below.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_214><loc_330><loc_220>Goal 1. Food Offered for Import Meets U.S. Food Safety Requirements</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_229><loc_443><loc_296>To ensure the safety of food imports, FDA will pursue objectives related to verification, enhanced compliance, and increased data and information sharing.  Specifically, FDA will optimize the use of foreign inspections and ensure importer use of verified foreign suppliers through implementation of the Foreign Supplier Verification Programs (FSVP) regulation.  FDA seeks to strengthen the capacity of foreign suppliers to produce safe food by increasing awareness of and training on food safety requirements and incentivizing importers to use verified suppliers of safe food through the Voluntary Qualified Importer Program (VQIP).  The agency also intends to work cooperatively with domestic and foreign regulatory counterparts to establish data and information sharing agreements designed to leverage each other's food and facility oversight.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_306><loc_310><loc_312>Goal 2. FDA Border Surveillance Prevents Entry of Unsafe Foods</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_321><loc_441><loc_357>The agency will continue to enhance and refine the import screening and entry review processes at the 300 plus U.S. ports of entry by improving testing methodologies and tools used to determine admissibility of food offered for import and optimizing the use of physical examinations and sampling of imported foods.  FDA also plans to strategically use import alerts and import certifications (one of the new tools under FSMA). 2/</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_367><loc_304><loc_373>Goal 3. Rapid and Effective Response to Unsafe Imported Food</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_382><loc_441><loc_411>FDA will take steps to enhance the efficiency and effectiveness of imported food safety recalls, such as by using information-sharing opportunities with regulatory counterparts with strong food safety systems.  When appropriate, FDA will exercise the mandatory recall authority granted to the agency by FSMA.</text>
<footnote><loc_59><loc_441><loc_441><loc_454>2/ Note that the Strategy does not provide any examples of the situations when FDA would use its import certification authority.</footnote>
<page_footer><loc_244><loc_463><loc_258><loc_468>- 2 -</page_footer>
<page_break>
<section_header_level_1><loc_59><loc_47><loc_258><loc_53>Goal 4. Effective and Efficient Food Import Program</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_59><loc_62><loc_436><loc_98>Longer term, the agency hopes to develop a comprehensive global inventory of food facilities and farms that intend to distribute food in the United States, which will allow FDA to assess the cumulative oversight applied to the imported food inventory.  The global inventory will also assist in accountability - FDA intends to publish performance measures and outcome metrics, as well as non-confidential data about imported food, foreign suppliers, and imports.</text>
<text><loc_219><loc_108><loc_228><loc_114>*</text>
<text><loc_248><loc_108><loc_257><loc_114>*</text>
<text><loc_278><loc_108><loc_284><loc_114>*</text>
<text><loc_59><loc_124><loc_438><loc_138>We will continue to monitor developments involving FDA's import strategy.  Please contact us if you have any questions.</text>
<page_footer><loc_244><loc_463><loc_258><loc_468>- 3 -</page_footer>
</doctag>

<section_header_level_1><loc_93><loc_91><loc_282><loc_97>Small Business Fees and Charges Rebate</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_93><loc_113><loc_463><loc_129>Are you a sole trader, the owner of a small business of a not-for-profit organisation? If you are, you may now be eligible for a small business fees and charges rebate of $1500.</text>
<text><loc_93><loc_145><loc_476><loc_183>'This rebate aims to help small businesses recover from the immense impacts of COVID-19,' said Warrumbungle Shire Council Mayor, Councillor Ambrose Doolan. 'Injecting $1500 into small businesses to assist with costs associated with running a business will assist many owners to get back on their feet after this unprecedented impact.'</text>
<text><loc_93><loc_198><loc_470><loc_247>The rebate can be used for eligible fees and charges that small businesses need to pay between 1 March 2021 until 30 June 2022. This includes, but is not limited to, food authority fees, liquor licences, tradesperson licences, events fees, and council rates. All fees and charges that are eligible for this rebate can be found at www.service.nsw.gov.au/smallbusiness-fees-and-charges-rebate</text>
<text><loc_93><loc_262><loc_464><loc_279>'Council would like to encourage all our small businesses across the region to jump online and have a look at the eligibility criteria and apply for this rebate,' said Cr Doolan.</text>
<text><loc_93><loc_294><loc_458><loc_322>'This is a fantastic opportunity to have business fees subsidised for the 2021/22 financial year, aiming to give NSW small businesses a boost while still recovering from the unexpected damage from COVID-19,' Cr Doolan concluded.</text>
<text><loc_93><loc_337><loc_463><loc_354>Eligible businesses may need a ServiceNSW Account to apply online. For those unable to apply online, call Service NSW on 13 77 88.</text>
<text><loc_93><loc_369><loc_462><loc_386>For more information contact Council's Manager Economic Development and Tourism, Jo Houghton on (02) 6849 2000.</text>
<text><loc_201><loc_412><loc_369><loc_418>Media: Leeanne Ryan | (02) 6849 2000</text>

What are the key guidelines set forth by the Department of Health for All Saints Preschool?

The key guidelines include maintaining small groups, having children with the same staff daily, rearranging furniture for social distancing, posting COVID-19 risk signage, staff wearing face coverings, and children being encouraged to wear face coverings.
What are the maximum student capacities for each classroom type in Plan A and who supervises them?

In Plan A, the maximum student capacities are: 2 Pre-k/k classrooms with a maximum of 20 students and 2 teachers, 1 three's classroom with a maximum of 18 students and 2 teachers, 1 two's young threes classroom with a maximum of 12 students and 1 teacher, and 1 toddler classroom with a maximum of 16 students and 3 teachers.
How does All Saints Preschool plan to manage drop-offs and pick-ups during the pandemic?

Parents will drop children off at the classroom door without entering the class. A staff member will perform temperature screening and a health check. Parents can pick up children at the classroom door as well, with a staff member escorting the child if needed. Only five parents are allowed in the facility at a time and they are limited to 5 minutes in the facility.
What additional measures are in place to minimize the risk of COVID-19 at All Saints Preschool?

Additional measures include parents sanitizing their hands upon entry, regular sanitizing of high touch surfaces and toys, playground time staggered for groups that share a yard, and temperature checks upon arrival, at lunch, and after nap.
What changes may occur in the student-to-teacher ratios of All Saints Preschool classrooms?
The student-to-teacher ratios may change depending on group sizes, and parents will be notified of any changes.

What are mid-actuator count deformable mirrors (DMs) used for?
Mid-actuator count DM systems are high performance wavefront correctors for demanding applications in astronomy, laser communications, and long-range imaging.
What are the three types of mid-actuator count DMs mentioned?
The three types of mid-actuator count DMs mentioned are the Kilo-DM, 492-DM, and the 648-DM.
What are the key features of the Kilo-DM system?

The Kilo-DM system has up to 1020 actuators controlled to under 1nm of precision and has no hysteresis, making it ideal for demanding applications requiring precise, high-speed, and high-resolution wavefront control.
How do the 492-DM and 648-DM systems compare to the Kilo-DM in terms of actuator count and cost-effectiveness?

The 492-DM and 648-DM systems have 492 and 648 actuators respectively, both controlled to under 1nm of precision and with no hysteresis. These systems offer powerful results at a lower cost compared to the Kilo-DM.
What is the frame rate and step resolution of the high-speed drive electronics for the mid actuator count DMs?
The high-speed drive electronics for the mid actuator count DMs are capable of a frame rate up to 60 kHz and a step resolution of 14 bits.
How do the 492-DM and 648-DM systems compare in terms of their response time?

The response time for both the 492-DM and 648-DM systems is below 100 microseconds, with the 492-DM having a response time of 17 microseconds (in low latency mode) and the 648-DM having a response time of 22 microseconds (in low latency mode).

What is the title of the 5-star restaurant in the village mentioned in the text?

What are the two types of cuisine served at Hansar Samui?
The two types of cuisine served at Hansar Samui are French-Mediterranean cuisine and traditional Thai cuisine.
What is unique about the dining area on the upper floor of Hansar Samui?
The dining area on the upper floor of Hansar Samui is known as 'Chill That' and offers an open-sided view over towards Koh when available.
What does the restaurant offer every Monday night?
The restaurant offers a Free Flow Mojito evening every Monday night.
How does the restaurant contribute to the island's beach bar culture?
The restaurant features a beach bar running a Free Flow Mojito evening, adding to the island's beach bar culture and attractions.
What types of premium beef are used in the dishes at Hansar Samui?
The dishes at Hansar Samui use imported Japanese Wagyu and Australian corn-fed beef.
What are the names of some of the set meals mentioned in the text?

How does Executive Chef, Stephen Dion, approach his culinary creations at Hansar Samui?
Executive Chef, Stephen Dion, has a modest approach to his culinary creations and keeps an eye on local ingredients, reinventing and tweaking old favorites to create new and interesting dishes.
What kind of entertainment can be found near Hansar Samui?
Near Hansar Samui, one can find performers and live bands along the main dining strip.
In what way is Hansar Samui connected to the Thai cuisine scene in Pha-Ngan?
Hansar Samui is a 5-star establishment in a popular Thai food destination, offering a premium dining experience alongside traditional Thai dishes and fresh seafood sourced locally from the island.

<doctag><section_header_level_1><loc_27><loc_34><loc_454><loc_68>5- S tar in the e V illage e 5 S tar in th V illag</section_header_level_1>
<picture><loc_10><loc_74><loc_486><loc_362></picture>
<text><loc_22><loc_369><loc_108><loc_458>It's one of the island's main attractions. It's busy most of the time. But on Friday, it gets hectic. That's when they have one of the best 'walking streets' on Samui. Everyone's there looking for bargains or seeing the sights. Stalls pack the streets, there are performers and live bands playing - there's a tantalising carnival atmosphere throughout. Happily, there are many bars and restaurants along the strip, as taking all this in can be thirsty work. Food, too. You're spoiled for choice when it comes to eats. But, right at the end, almost un-noticed amongst all this fun, sits Hansar. And that's where the locals head when they need to take a quality break. The facilities are superb and the service, world-class. The spa suite is the height of luxury and yet with serious programs of holistic well-being, too. And, going by the simple name of 'H Bistro', the restaurant has become something of a legend since it opened.</text>
<text><loc_22><loc_464><loc_108><loc_485>It's worth mentioning that there are actually two restaurants here. H Bistro, as already outlined, takes up the lower floor of the two-storey block, butting up right against the beach road of Fisherman's Village. About as close as you can</text>
<text><loc_116><loc_369><loc_201><loc_426>get to the sea without being actually in it, and with a great open-sided view over towards Koh Pha-Ngan. The upper floor is the laid-back Chill Lounge. Although this was initially seen as a kind of 'meet 'n' greet' venue, it quickly lent itself to an alternative dining area to H Bistro beneath. Whereas the lower dining area is more traditional, with sturdy wooden tables and dining chairs, upstairs there are big comfortable sofas together with day beds and low tables, and the waiter service from downstairs means that you can enjoy your meal as well as being, literally, very laid back!</text>
<text><loc_116><loc_432><loc_201><loc_485>Executive Chef, Stephen Dion, is a very modest man, preferring to beaver away like an artist in his garret behind the scenes, creating new gastronomic works and tweaking old favourites. That's not to say he's any kind of hermit; on the contrary, he's often to be seen talking quietly with his guests and greeting new diners. But it means he's the last person who'd ever stand up and shout about his skills - no doubt one of the qualities that previously prompted His Majesty the King of Jordan to recruit Stephen to be his personal chef. The menu here is quite superb,</text>
<text><loc_209><loc_369><loc_294><loc_404>being distinctly a light, clean bias towards French-Mediterranean cuisine, but with an added emphasis on seafood. In this case, that means live lobster shipped-in from abroad, or live razor clams and langoustines from Scotland, oysters from Japan and mussels from Australia, depending on what's in season. Plus, naturally, Japanese Wagyu and Australian corn-fed beef.</text>
<text><loc_209><loc_410><loc_295><loc_458>'I like to feature seafood,' Stephen observed, 'because it's what most people seem to want. Obviously, it's because we're an island. But it's also a great favourite of mine. So as well as the locally caught items, I'm always keeping an eye out for something unusual or interesting. One of the current specials is the amazing yellow fin tuna. It's darker and firmer than you'd expect, and the taste is fuller. Likewise, the swordfish is from Sri Lanka, and it stays really delicate and moist.'</text>
<text><loc_209><loc_464><loc_294><loc_485>But to my mind one of the most fascinating sections of the menu at Hansar can't be claimed by Stephen at all! It's the Thai menu, courtesy of Chef Boonson. And if you enjoy Thai food, then this is an absolute must. It's not fancy, there are</text>
<text><loc_302><loc_369><loc_388><loc_422>no pretensions to 'fusion' or other such fads, but it's special on several counts. Firstly, it's all made with quality, prime ingredients, unlike general Thai cuisine. And the difference that a plump corn-fed chicken or an imported cut of beef can make is simply startling. And second, the sauces and pastes are all Khun Boonson's own recipes - again, using imported or top-quality ingredients. The combination of these two aspects makes the à la carte Thai menu really something to sample. But there's an extra, added attraction, too.</text>
<text><loc_302><loc_428><loc_388><loc_485>Titled the 'Discovery Menu', it's a set meal for two people, beginning with 'Yam Talay' seafood soup. But, in keeping with the gourmet approach, what you actually get is 'seared Thai Gulf sea prawn, squid and mussels, together with tomato, red chili, celery and spring onions, in a spicy seafood sauce'. There is then a similarly excellent 'Tom Kha Gai' (coconut soup) followed by a choice of either 'Pla Kapong Neung Manao' (steamed sea bass) or 'Zee Clong Kae/Moo Phad Prik Thai On' (slow-cooked lamb or pork ribs in garlic). The dessert is 'Thai Gluey Tord' (batter fried bananas with maple syrup)</text>
<text><loc_395><loc_369><loc_480><loc_386>and a choice of tea of coffee to finish. If you love Thai food but have never had it prepared and presented like this, then this is where to go to discover a new dimension!</text>
<text><loc_395><loc_392><loc_481><loc_444>However (and this depends on your view of life!) I've saved the best until last. The very chic beach bar is running a Free Flow Mojito evening every Monday night. There are a dozen alluring fruity flavours to go for, and the cost is just 450 baht per person, for as much as you want to sup. It kicks in at 7:30 pm, and you can wiggle your toes right through until 9:30 pm. Plus, come with four people and one person drinks for free! And that's the best intro to the 5-star Hansar Samui I can think of. So next time you go to Walking Street - just keep on walking!</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_395><loc_458><loc_420><loc_463>Rob De Wet</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_395><loc_469><loc_467><loc_481>For reservations or further information, telephone 0 7724 5511. www.hansarsamui.com</text>
</doctag>
What is the purpose of the Priority of Employment list, also known as the Recall List?

The Purpose of the Priority of Employment list, also known as the Recall List, is for the School Board to use when all regular teachers under contract have been placed and there are still jobs to fill.
What are the obligations of the School Board for teachers with two years or more of seniority on the Recall List?

For teachers on the recall list with two years or more of seniority, the School Board must offer a "regular" contract if it has a post available for which the teacher is qualified. A regular contract continues from year to year.
How does the School Board fulfill its obligations for teachers with less than two years of seniority on the Recall List?

For teachers with less than two years of seniority, the School Board’s obligations are to offer any part-time posts available, including 100% replacement positions. These posts terminate at the end of the school year or with the return of the absent teacher, if they are replacement posts, whichever comes first.
What are the eligibility criteria for a teacher to get onto the Recall List?

To get onto the recall list, a teacher must be legally qualified, have obtained two contracts (of at least 100 days each) in two different school years during the last three years, and require two satisfactory performance evaluations in two years.
When are hiring halls dates typically sent to each teacher on the Recall List?

In June, the School Board sends to each teacher on the recall list a letter informing them of the hiring halls dates (one for high school posts and one for elementary posts other than category 101 – English generalists).
What is the eligibility requirement for a teacher to be on a recall list in the Vocational Training sector?

To be eligible to be on a recall list in the Vocational Training sector, a teacher must have taught 720 hours in 2 out of the last 3 school years in vocational education, and have received a satisfactory evaluation.
How does the School Board fulfill its obligations for teachers on the Vocational Training Recall List?

Once on a recall list, the School Board has the obligation to offer as many 720-hour posts as possible to the teachers on the list, by seniority. The School Board also has the obligation to offer any part-time posts available by this same method.
How are contracts awarded to teachers who acquire 720-hour workloads prior to December 1st in the Vocational Training sector?

Contracts of 486 hours or more equal one year of seniority. The contracts that are awarded to teachers who acquire 720-hour workloads prior to December 1st and who hold a Quebec teaching permit are automatically renewable and are called “full-time” contracts.
What are the eligibility requirements for a teacher to be on the recall list in Adult Education?
To be eligible to be on the recall list in Adult Education, a teacher must have taught 800 hours in 2 out of the last 3 school years in adult education, and have received a satisfactory evaluation.
How does the School Board fulfill its obligations for teachers on the Adult Education Recall List?

Once on the recall list, the School Board has the obligation to offer as many 800-hour (full-time) posts as possible to the teachers on the list. Hiring is done at a placement meeting by seniority. The School Board also has the obligation to offer any part-time posts available by this same method. Teachers who acquire a workload of at least 240 hours in a given school year and who hold a Quebec teaching permit must be given part-time contracts.

<text><loc_58><loc_188><loc_444><loc_210>To  get  onto  the  recall  list,  a  teacher  must  be  legally  qualified  (within  the  meaning  of  1-1.35 Provincial  Entente)  and  must  have  obtained  two  contracts  (of  at  least  100  days  each)  in  two different school years during the last three years.</text>
<text><loc_58><loc_220><loc_445><loc_234>In  order  to  be  placed  on  the  recall  list,  a  teacher  requires  two  satisfactory  performance evaluations in two years.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_58><loc_244><loc_147><loc_250>How is the list used?</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_58><loc_260><loc_445><loc_282>In June, the School Board sends to each teacher on the recall list a letter informing them of the hiring halls dates  (one  for  high  school  posts  and  one  for  elementary  posts  other  than category 101 Ð English generalists).</text>
<text><loc_58><loc_292><loc_445><loc_322>In August (usually a week before the end of the summer holidays), the third and final hiring hall takes place. <section_header_level_1><loc_58><loc_332><loc_174><loc_338>Vocational Training Sector</section_header_level_1>

<section_header_level_1><loc_58><loc_102><loc_160><loc_108>Adult Education Sector</section_header_level_1>

<text><loc_58><loc_214><loc_438><loc_268>Provisions for getting a full-time (i.e., full-time and AUTOMATICALLY RENEWABLE) contract are determined in the provincial contract. That number is added to the number of teachers who already hold full-time contracts. If the latter number is less than 75% of the total, then new full-time contracts must be issued to bring the number up to at least 75% of the total.</text>

What is the summary of the Parish Councillor Job Description?

The Parish Councillor Job Description outlines the responsibilities of a Parish Councillor, who is responsible to the Council and its electors. Their role involves effective leadership, bringing local issues to the Council's attention, making decisions for the local community, and representing the views of parishioners. The position is voluntary and does not involve salary.
What are some of the main duties and responsibilities of a Parish Councillor as mentioned in the document?

The main duties and responsibilities of a Parish Councillor include participating constructively in parish governance, forming and scrutinizing policies, budgets, strategies, and service delivery, ensuring proper management of the Parish Council, staying updated with developments affecting the Parish Council, being accessible and representing effectively the interests of the Ward, attending council meetings, forming sound judgements, maintaining proper standards of behavior, fulfilling statutory and locally determined requirements, and participating effectively in committees or working parties.
What qualifications and characteristics are required for a Parish Councillor according to the Person Specification?

According to the Person Specification, a Parish Councillor must be over 18 and on the electoral register, a resident of the parish they are standing for (or within a 3-mile radius of the Ward), able to attend regular evening meetings, have an interest in local issues, and be willing to represent the views of the community.
Is the Parish Councillor position a paid role?
No, the Parish Councillor position is voluntary and does not involve a salary.
How long is the period of service for a Parish Councillor?
The period of service for a Parish Councillor is four years.

<text><loc_45><loc_215><loc_432><loc_229>There is a legal requirement for Parish Councillors to attend council meetings and abide by the code of conduct.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_45><loc_239><loc_173><loc_245>Main Duties and Responsibilities</section_header_level_1>
<unordered_list><list_item><loc_61><loc_255><loc_308><loc_261>1. To participate constructively in the government of the parish.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_263><loc_448><loc_277>2. To participate fully in the formation and scrutiny of the parish councils policies, budgets, strategies and service delivery, including the Community Plan.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_279><loc_370><loc_285>3. To ensure, with fellow councillors that the Parish Council is properly managed</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_287><loc_448><loc_301>4. To keep up to date with significant developments affecting the Parish Council at local, regional and national levels.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_302><loc_441><loc_317>5. To be accessible and to represent effectively the interests of the Ward of which the Councillor is elected and deal with parishioner's enquiries, representations and complaints without prejudice.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_318><loc_446><loc_333>6. To attend parish council meetings and to prepare and be properly informed about the issues to be discussed. (Calendar of meetings attached)</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_334><loc_444><loc_357>7. To take part in meeting and to form sound judgements based on facts of what is best for the community ensuring that any decisions are representative of the community the elected member represents.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_358><loc_447><loc_373>8. To maintain proper standards of behaviour as an elected representative of the people and to treat everyone with respect.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_374><loc_438><loc_397>9. To fulfil the statutory and locally determined requirements of an elected member of a Local Authority and the parish Council, including compliance with all relevant codes of conduct and to maintain high ethical standards.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_398><loc_452><loc_413>10. To participate effectively as a member of any committee or working party to which the Councillor is appointed.</list_item>
<list_item><loc_61><loc_414><loc_450><loc_429>11. To undertake appropriate training and development to help fulfil the requirement of the Councillor role.</list_item>
</unordered_list>

The main topic of the text is the relationship between COVID-19 and diabetes, including the epidemiological evidence, physiological mechanisms, novel presentation of diabetes in COVID-19 patients, and treatment strategies.

Who is the author of the presentation and what is his professional background?
The author of the presentation is David Hopkins, a consultant physician and diabetologist based in London. He is the Director of the Institute of Diabetes, Endocrinology and Obesity at King's Health Partners, and has broad clinical and academic interests across the entire spectrum of diabetes. His research covers novel endoscopic based treatments for type 2 diabetes, using large datasets to understand the clinical course of diabetes, and improving the understanding of the experience living with diabetes.

How has the perceived risk of COVID-19 changed during the pandemic?
Initially, the condition was perceived to be of greatest risk to people with underlying pulmonary disease. However, the threat has shifted towards predominating in those with diabetes and metabolic dysfunction.

What are the main priorities for clinical practice and public health mentioned in the text?
The main priorities are to understand how diabetes can lead to severe COVID-19 and how COVID-19 can complicate diabetes pathophysiology or its outcomes.

What topics will the presentation cover?
The presentation will cover the epidemiological evidence for links between COVID-19 and diabetes, the underlying physiological mechanisms that may place people with diabetes at increased risk, a novel presentation of diabetes in COVID-19 patients, and the lessons learnt on the clinical challenges and optimal treatment strategies for managing people with diabetes and acute COVID-19 infection.

What are David Hopkins' current research interests?
David Hopkins' current research interests range from novel endoscopic based treatments for type 2 diabetes, to the use of large datasets to understand the clinical course of diabetes, and improving the understanding of the experience living with diabetes.

What educational program is David Hopkins leading, and when will it launch?
David Hopkins is leading a new King's College London online Masters level program in diabetes, which will launch in 2021.
Convert this page to docling.

<doctag><section_header_level_1><loc_61><loc_45><loc_107><loc_51>ABSTRACT</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_61><loc_60><loc_442><loc_96>A striking feature of the COVID-19 pandemic has been the gradual transition from a condition perceived as being of greatest risk to people with underlying pulmonary disease to one where the threat is seen to predominate in those with diabetes and metabolic dysfunction.</text>
<text><loc_61><loc_105><loc_431><loc_141>This reflects a complex interplay between COVID-19 and diabetes. Understanding how diabetes can lead to severe COVID-19 and conversely, how COVID-19 can complicate diabetes pathophysiology or its outcomes, is an important priority for clinical practice and public health.</text>
<text><loc_61><loc_150><loc_441><loc_195>In this presentation we will review the epidemiological evidence for links between COVID-19 and diabetes, the underlying physiological mechanisms that may place people with diabetes at increased risk and the evidence for a novel presentation of diabetes in COVID-19.  We will also consider the lessons learnt so far on the clinical challenges and optimal treatment strategies for managing people with diabetes and acute COVID-19 infection.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_61><loc_219><loc_173><loc_225>David Hopkins - biography</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_61><loc_233><loc_442><loc_289>David Hopkins is a consultant physician and diabetologist based in London. He is Director of the Institute of Diabetes, Endocrinology and Obesity at King's Health Partners, an academic health science centre comprising King's College London, King's College Hospital, Guy's & St Thomas' Hospitals and South London & Maudsley NHS trust. He is Co-Chair of the Council of Healthcare  Professionals  at  Diabetes  UK  and  is  a  former  member  of  the  UK  DAFNE collaborative executive.</text>
<text><loc_61><loc_298><loc_442><loc_354>David has broad clinical and academic interests across the whole spectrum of diabetes and runs  specialist  clinics for advanced  type  1  diabetes  management  islet  and  pancreas transplantation and diabetes complication management.  Current research work ranges from studies on novel endoscopic based treatments for type 2 diabetes to the use of large datasets to  understand  the  clinical  course  of  diabetes  and  improving  the  understanding  of  the experience living with diabetes.</text>
<text><loc_61><loc_363><loc_442><loc_389>David has been actively engaged in multidisciplinary health professional education throughout his career and is leading on a new King's College London online Masters level programme which will launch in 2021.</text>
</doctag>
The main topic of the document is problems experienced when connecting two Lio-8 3D instruments via USB and possible solutions.

The key points discussed include: the user's Mac system specifications, the issue of loss of sound when connecting via USB, the lack of issue when connecting via Ethernet, experimentation with buffer size and channel count, and the specific problem with Ableton Live and buffer size when using Ethernet.

The author supports their argument that the USB connection causes sound interruption by providing evidence that the problem does not occur when using an Ethernet connection or when reducing the number of channels used.

From the document, it can be inferred that the user has attempted various solutions to the USB connection issue, such as adjusting buffer size and reducing channel count, and that the issue is specific to Ableton Live.

The implications of the problems mentioned in the document are that the user may need to switch to an Ethernet connection for reliable performance when using multiple Lio-8 3D instruments with Ableton Live, or find a workaround for the compatibility issues between USB multi-boxes and Ableton Live.

What is the price of a 12oz glass of Prosecco from Italy listed under The Travel From Home Spring Menu?
The price of a 12oz glass of Prosecco from Italy listed under The Travel From Home Spring Menu is $9.
Where is The Jacqueline cocktail made and what are its main ingredients?
The Jacqueline cocktail is made in Paris, and its main ingredients include rosé, pomegranate, and white wine.
Where is the tamarillo grown for the Tropicália IPA syrup, and what type of beer is it brewed with?
The tamarillo is grown in Paso Robles, and the Tropicália IPA is brewed with Lunazul Blanco Tequila.
What is the origin of the wine used in the Down-Home Old-Fashioned cocktail, and what are some of its flavor notes?

The wine used in the Down-Home Old-Fashioned cocktail is Barbera from the Weller Special Reserve Bourbon, and it has hints of raspberry and is paired with sour cherry juice, Luxardo Maraschino, and Smoked Orange bitters.
What is the collaboration between the Giol and Tequila Avion for the Tropicália IPA, and how does the yeast contribute to the beer's aroma?
The collaboration between the Giol and Tequila Avion for the Tropicália IPA involves infusing tropical juices into the beer, with the yeast adding a spicy malty aroma reminiscent of Mexican food.
What is the historical significance of the house in Sarasota, FL, and what are some other cocktails listed in the text?

The house in Sarasota, FL was brought over from Vermont in 1974 and is said to be where Margaret Thatcher found her friend's gnat, which then inspired a cocktail. Other cocktails listed in the text include the Adonis Cocktail, Louise Cocktail, Last Word, and Martinez Cocktail.
What unique ingredient is used in the Blenheim Saison Bar Pub's "Be There with You" cocktail, and what are some flavor notes described in the text?

The Unique ingredient used in the Blenheim Saison Bar Pub's "Be There with You" cocktail is Blenheim apricot whiskey. Flavor notes described in the text include a rich blend of apricot and vanilla, with citrus accents and hints of floral and spice notes.

What is the primary focus of the Community College of Baltimore County course outline description?

The primary focus of the course outline is to provide instruction in basic pharmacology and medication administration for a variety of animal species, while also discussing the effects of toxins on animals.
What are the prerequisites for the course VETT 212 – Pharmacology and Toxicology?
The prerequisites for the course are VETT 107 and VETT 109.
What are the main objectives upon completion of the VETT 212 – Pharmacology and Toxicology course?

Upon completion of the course, students will be able to compare drug classifications and actions, analyze factors affecting medication action, apply abbreviations, identify medication order components, distinguish side effects and reactions, discuss safe medication administration, demonstrate competency in dosage calculations, maintain veterinary pharmacy and inventory, record controlled substances, and examine drug and toxicology effects on the body's systems.
Under the Major Topics section, which categories are discussed under the medication classifications?
The categories discussed under medication classifications include Cardiovascular, Respiratory, Endocrine, Analgesics, Antibiotics, Immunizations, and Gastrointestinal.
What topics are covered in the Veterinary pharmacy management and inventory section?
The topics covered in the Veterinary pharmacy management and inventory section include procedures for maintaining veterinary pharmacy and drug inventory.
What topics are addressed in the Drug administration section of the course outline?
The Drug administration section addresses the components of safe medication administration for various species.
Which topics are included in the Toxicology section of the course outline?
The Toxicology section includes the effects of drugs on the body's systems and examines the toxicology effects.
What are the grading procedures for the VETT 212 – Pharmacology and Toxicology course?

The grading procedures will include a minimum of three examinations, a minimum of two quizzes, and written assignments that adhere to the American Psychological Association (APA) format. The specific grading details will be determined by the individual faculty member.
What are the learning outcomes of the Pharmacology and Toxicology course?

Upon completion of the Pharmacology and Toxicology course, students will be able to compare drug classifications and actions of medications, analyze factors that may affect the action of selected medications, apply commonly approved abbreviations, identify the components of the medication order, distinguish medication side effects, adverse reactions, and implications, discuss the components of safe medication administration for various species, demonstrate competency in dosage calculations, examine the procedure for maintaining the veterinary pharmacy and drug inventory, execute the procedure for recording controlled substances, and of drugs on the body’s systems.
What major topics are covered in the Pharmacology and Toxicology course?

The major topics covered in the Pharmacology and Toxicology course include: Medication nomenclature, Pharmacodynamics, Approved abbreviations, Medication orders, Medication classifications (Cardiovascular, Respiratory, Endocrine, Analgesics, Antibiotics, Immunizations, Gastrointestinal, Genitourinary), Euthanasia, Dosage (Weights and measures, Calculating dehydration, Intravenous calculations), Veterinary pharmacy management and inventory, Drug administration, Controlled substances, and Toxicology.
What are the grading processes and requirements for the Pharmacology and Toxicology course?

The grading procedures will be determined by the individual faculty member but will include a minimum of three examinations, a minimum of two quizzes, and written assignments that require students to use appropriate academic resources and submit all work in American Psychological Association (APA) format.
What are some of the general objectives for students in the Veterinary Technology Program?

Students in the Veterinary Technology Program will learn a variety of skills, including the care and management of animals, the administration of medications and medications, the management of a professional veterinary practice, the basics of business and finance as it relates to running a veterinary clinic, and the use of technology and equipment in a veterinary setting. Specific objectives may vary depending on the focus of the program.
Based on the course description, what topics related to pharmacology and toxicology are discussed in the course?

Topics related to pharmacology and toxicology that are discussed in the course include basic pharmacology, the action of medications on a variety of animal species, how toxins affect animals, medication classifications and actions, factors that may affect medication action, approved abbreviations, medication orders, side effects, adverse reactions, safe medication administration for various species, dosage calculations, maintaining a veterinary pharmacy and drug inventory, recording controlled substances, and toxicology effects.

What is the main purpose of the letter being sent to parents/carers?
The main purpose of the letter is to outline the high expectations regarding school uniform from September 2021 at RHS.
What does the School Uniform and Equipment Policy document cover?
The School Uniform and Equipment Policy document clearly outlines the expectations in terms of appropriate trouser and skirt styles and lengths, socks and footwear.
What types of accessories are not permitted as part of the school uniform?
Accessories such as rings, necklaces, bracelets, false nails, facial piercing, extreme hairstyles and false eyelashes are not permitted.
What is the purpose of the Uniform Guide and Leaflet for parents/carers?

The purpose of the Uniform Guide and Leaflet for parents/carers is to assist parents/carers in making appropriate choices the first time and to avoid informing them in September that they have purchased clothing and/or footwear that will not be acceptable.
Where can parents/carers purchase school uniform logo items?
Parents/carers can purchase school uniform logo items from RAM Leisure, located at Whitegates Industrial Complex, Wrexham, LL13 8UG.
When did the school Uniform Grant come into effect?
The school Uniform Grant came into effect from September 2018.
Who should parents/carers contact if they have any concerns regarding uniform?
Parents/carers should contact their child's Progress Manager for clarification if they have any concerns regarding uniform.
What is the purpose of RHS's school uniform policy?
The purpose of RHS's school uniform policy is to uphold the school’s ethos and high standards by ensuring that all students wear full school uniform correctly at all times without exception.
What items are not permitted in the RHS school uniform policy?
The items not permitted in the RHS school uniform policy include rings, necklaces, bracelets, false nails, facial piercing, extreme hairstyles, and false eyelashes.
What is the recommendation for parents/carers before purchasing school uniform items?

The recommendation for parents/car owners before purchasing school uniform items is to read the school uniform guidance and policy, and to refer to the Uniform Guide and Leaflet for parents/carers to clarify what constitutes the stated RHS uniform.
Which company is authorized by RHS as the official supplier of their school uniform logo items?
RAM Leisure, located at Whitegates Industrial Complex, Wrexham, is the authorized supplier of RHS school uniform logo items.
What is the purpose of the School Uniform Grant mentioned in the text?
The purpose of the School Uniform Grant, which came into effect from September 2018, is to provide financial assistance to parents/carers for purchasing school uniform items.
Who should parents/carers contact if they have any concerns regarding uniform?
Parents/carers should contact their child's Progress Manager for clarification if they have any concerns regarding uniform.
What is the mission statement of RHS?
The mission statement of RHS is "RESPECT HONESTY SUCCESS," which encompasses the school's values and ethos.

<text><loc_60><loc_67><loc_141><loc_73>Dear Parent/Carer,</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_82><loc_442><loc_118>As we begin to move into a new phase and look ahead to the next academic year, I would like to  outline  our  high  expectations  regarding  school  uniform  from  September  2021.  At  RHS, school uniform is a vital aspect of our school's ethos and high standards. When school returns after the summer break all students are expected to wear full school uniform correctly at all time without exception.</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_127><loc_442><loc_163>The two documents which accompany this letter include the School Uniform and Equipment Policy (attached) which clearly outlines our expectations in terms of appropriate trouser and skirt styles and lengths, socks and footwear. Items such as rings, necklaces, bracelets, false nails, facial piercing, extreme hairstyles and false eyelashes are not permitted. Earrings should be a single stud in each earlobe only.</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_172><loc_442><loc_208>The second document entitled the Uniform Guide and Leaflet for parents/carers (attached) should be read in conjunction with the policy.  The purpose of this leaflet is to help assist parents/carers  in  making  appropriate  choices  the  first  time.  We  do  not  want  to  inform parents/carers in September that they have purchased clothing and/or footwear that will not be acceptable.</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_218><loc_442><loc_246>We would ask our parents/carers to take time to look through the pictures in the leaflet, to clarify what constitutes the stated Rhosnesni High School uniform in terms of shoes, socks, trousers and skirts.  Whilst this doesn't cover every possible style, hopefully it will be of help in providing a better idea of what is expected.</text>
<section_header_level_1><loc_60><loc_255><loc_185><loc_261>Purchasing School Uniform</section_header_level_1>
<text><loc_60><loc_270><loc_442><loc_306>The school has entered into partnership with RAM Leisure, Whitegates Industrial Complex, Wrexham, LL13 8UG (01978) 360360, www.ramleisure.com. They are the only supplier of our school uniform logo items. The company is uniquely placed to be able to offer the purchase of good value, quality uniform and other essentials. Please ensure that you have read the school uniform guidance and policy before purchasing uniform items.</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_315><loc_442><loc_336>The school Uniform Grant, came into effect from September 2018. For further details please click  onto  the  Uniform  Grant  section  in  the  Transition  Pack  on  our  school  website  or  visit WCBC website.</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_345><loc_442><loc_359>If you have any concerns regarding uniform please contact your child's Progress Manager for clarification.</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_368><loc_416><loc_374>Finally, I would like to take this opportunity to wish you and your family a safe summer.</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_383><loc_126><loc_389>Yours sincerely</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_397><loc_99><loc_404>V Brown</text>
<text><loc_60><loc_413><loc_148><loc_427>Miss V Brown Deputy Headteacher</text>

What were the general observations in Telangana's People's Plan Campaign (PPC) report for the years 2017 and 2018?

The general observations include the number of facilitators appointed, Gram Panchayats (GP) uploaded the Frontline Professional Improvement (P-I-B) Reports, special GP identified, number of Meetings Held in GP, the Physical Progress of the last year, the Financial Progress of the last year, and the account release for the fiscal year 2018-19.
How many facilitators were appointed during the years 2017 and 2018 in the People's Plan Campaign in Telangana?
A total of 12,751 facilitators were appointed in 2017 and 8,058 facilitators were appointed in 2018.
How many grams were identified as special grams in the years 2017 and 2018?
In both 2017 and 2018, a total of 8,058 special grams were identified.
How many Gram Sabha meetings were held in 2017 and 2018 respectively in Telangana under the People's Plan Campaign?
In 2017, 20,581 Gram Sabha meetings were held and in 2018, 18,556 Gram Sabha meetings were held.
How many participants underwent GPDP training during the previous year (2017-18) in Telangana?
During the previous year (2017-18), 1,73,682 participants underwent GPDP training in Telangana.
Were there any on account funds released to the Telangana state government for the fiscal year 2018-19?
No, there were no on account funds released to the Telangana state government for the fiscal year 2018-19.
Under the Institutional Structure component of the annual action plan, what is the proposed reimbursement rate per month per block in Telangana?
The State has proposed a reimbursement rate of Rs. 40,000 per month per block under the Institutional Structure component of the annual action plan in Telangana.
How many computers, printers, and scanners are planned to be provided for Gram Panchayats (GPs) under the E-enablement component in Telangana, and what is the cost per GP?
A total of 532 computers, printers, and scanners are planned to be provided for Gram Panchayats (GPs) under the E-enablement component in Telangana, with a cost of Rs. 40,000 per GP.

What is the summary of the text?

The text is a digital version of The Book of Discipline of The United Methodist Church, outlining the denominational law, doctrine, administration, and procedures. It also mentions a free online edition available for download and provides links to additional information and resources.
What is the historical background of The Book of Discipline of The United Methodist Church?

The Book of Discipline was first published in 1784, in the Methodist Episcopal Church, and has been published every four years thereafter following the meeting of the General Conference, which passes legislation that is included in the Book of Discipline.
How does The Book of Discipline relate to previous denominations?
The Book of Discipline follows similar works for its predecessor denominations, reflecting their influence on the United Methodist Church's policies and procedures.
What is the purpose of The Book of Discipline?

The Book of Discipline sets forth the plan by which the United Methodist Church governs itself, reflects its understanding of the Church, and outlines what is expected of the laity and clergy. It serves as a guide for members to live in true discipleship of Jesus Christ.
Does The Book of Discipline contain any information about sacraments and worship?
Yes, under the discipline of the Holy Spirit, the church seeks to provide for the maintenance of worship and the education of believers, as stated in The Book of Discipline.
What is the WCA Council's involvement with the draft of a "Book of Doctrines and Discipline"?
The WCA Council has reviewed portions of the draft and delivered it to the 2019 WCA Global Legislative Assembly, which contains sections on Doctrines and Doctrinal Standards.
How can one access The Book of Discipline of The United Methodist Church 2012 in ebook format?
The book is available for free download with shipping, or it can be purchased online from Barnes & Noble. However, due to COVID-19, orders may be delayed.

What is the main focus of the document?
The main focus of the document is to provide detailed specifications and certifications for a specific dry-cured sausage label facestock, Supertack adhesive, and Glassine Ambar 62 liner.
What are the significant details mentioned about the facestock?

The facestock is a superior gloss coated woodfree paper with high stiffness and high tensile strength. Its applications are specially designed for dry-cured sausage labels, and it is suitable for various printing techniques.
How does Supertack adhesive work, and for which surfaces is it designed?

Supertack is a strong and aggressive acrylic permanent adhesive with excellent tack and final adhesion. It is designed for difficult surfaces such as wood boxes, slightly wet surfaces, rough plastics, and LDPE.
What is the shelf life of Supertack adhesive, and what conditions should it be stored in?
The shelf life of Supertack adhesive is 2 years, and it should be stored at 20ºC and 50% relative humidity.
What certifications and standards are associated with the self-adhesive division of Lecta's main operational offices?

The self-adhesive division's facility is certified to the strictest environmental standards ISO 14001 and EMAS. It has successfully completed audits for ISO 50001, ISO 9001, and ISO 45001 certification.
What are the paper specifications for Glassine Ambar 62 liner?

Glassine Ambar 62 liner is a super-calendered translucent glassine paper. Its specifications include a substance of 62 g/m² with a tolerance of 59-65, a thickness of 52 µm with a tolerance of 50-58, and a color of yellow.
What types of printing techniques are suitable for the facestock?

The suitable printing techniques for the facestock include flexo (all types), letterpress (conventional and UV), screen printing, hot stamping, thermal transfer, laser, conventional offset, and offset UV.
What temperature ranges are specified for the facestock, adhesive, and liner in terms of minimum, service, and maximum temperatures?
The minimum labelling temperature is -7ºC, minimum service temperature is -20ºC, and the maximum service temperature is +60ºC for the facestock, adhesive, and liner.
What directives and safety standards are associated with the facestock, adhesive, and liner?

The associated directives and safety standards include the Packaging and packaging waste Directive 94/62/CE, contact with foodstuff (BfR XXXVI), EN 1230 Sensorial analysis, EN 71-3 Toy safety, and Electric and electronic equipment (RoHS).
Are Adestor paper products available with specific certifications?
Yes, Adestor paper products are available with PEFC™ and FSC® chain of custody certificates upon request.
What is the Art number of the Supertack product?
The Art number of the Supertack product is 225.
What are the main properties of the woodfree paper described in the text?
The woodfree paper has superior gloss, high stiffness, and high tensile strength.
For what applications is the described paper specially designed?
The described paper is specially designed for dry-cured sausage labels.
List the printing techniques suitable for the described woodfree paper.

The suitable printing techniques for the described woodfree paper are flexo, letterpress (conventional and UV), screen printing, hot printing techniques, stamping, thermal transfer, laser, conventional offset, and offset UV.
What are the ISO standards for the paper's properties like thickness, smoothness, brightness, whiteness, and paper gloss?
The ISO standards for the paper's properties are ISO 534 for thickness, ISO 5627 for smoothness, ISO 2470-2 for brightness, ISO 11475 for whiteness, and ISO 8254-1 for paper gloss.
What is the main feature of the Supertack product, and on what types of surfaces is it suitable?

The main feature of the Supertack product is that it is a specially strong and aggressive acrylic permanent adhesive with excellent tack and final adhesion. It is suitable for difficult surfaces such as wood boxes, slightly wet surfaces, rough plastics, and LDPE.
How long is the shelf life of the Supertack product, and under what storage conditions?
The shelf life of the Supertack product is 2 years, from the date of manufacture, and it should be stored at 20ºC and 50% relative humidity.
What is the glassine liner used for, and what are its properties?

The glassine liner is used for automatic labelling, and its properties include good tear resistance, smooth and regular thickness, and it is especially designed for sensorial analysis applications and photocell dispensing systems.
What certifications does Adestor's self-adhesive mill hold?
Adestor's self-adhesive mill holds ISO 14001, EMAS, and has been audited for ISO 50001, ISO 9001, and ISO 45001 certifications.
What are the environmental certificates that Adestor paper products are available with upon request?
Adestor paper products are available with PEFC™ and FSC® chain of custody certificates upon request.

What is the significance of door-to-balloon time (DBT) in the management of STEMI patients?

The significance of door-to-balloon time (DBT) in the management of STEMI patients is that it is an indicator of the quality of care, and a shorter DBT is associated with better patient outcomes. The risk of mortality from STEMI decreases when the DBT is achieved in a shorter time frame, with recommended thresholds being <60 minutes and <90 minutes for optimal outcomes.
What measures were taken to achieve a shorter door-to-balloon time in this study?

Organizational measures such as preparing protocols, staff education including of those in the emergency unit, having an in-house PCI-capable team, performing an echocardiogram after the procedure, conducting the procedure after a financial agreement form without waiting for payments, and patient education through media and meetings were taken to achieve a shorter door-to-balloon time in this study.
What was the most common infarct-related artery (IRA) in this study?
The most common infarct-related artery (IRA) in this study was the left anterior descending artery.
What were the main reasons for the patients' delay in reaching the hospital, as mentioned in the text?

The main reasons for the patients' delay in reaching the hospital included fewer patients using ambulance services, delay at local hospitals, inaccurate diagnosis, lack of awareness, and longer distance from the hospital.
What can be done to improve pre-hospital care and reduce the total ischaemia time in STEMI patients?

Improving pre-hospital care and reducing the total ischaemia time in STEMI patients can be achieved by focusing on the patient delay, improving the network of nearby hospitals and ambulance services, taking measures to achieve a shorter door-to-balloon time, and providing patient education through media and meetings.
What is the median symptom onset to hospital arrival time reported in the study, and how does it compare to the median door-to-balloon time?
The median symptom onset to hospital arrival time reported in the study is 352 minutes, and the median door-to-balloon time is 60 minutes.
What is the major reason for the loss of time in achieving a shorter door-to-balloon time, according to the study?
The major reason for the loss of time is the delay in taking decisions for primary PCI by relatives of the patient due to a lack of awareness of the time-critical nature of the procedure.
According to the study, what is the acceptable median door-to-balloon time within the range recommended by guidelines?
The acceptable median door-to-balloon time within the range recommended by guidelines is 60 minutes.
What strategies were implemented to achieve a shorter door-to-balloon time in the study?

Strategies to achieve a shorter door-to-balloon time included preparing protocols, staff education, having an in-house PCI-capable team, performing echocardiography after the procedure, undertaking the procedure after a financial agreement form without waiting for payments, and patient education through media and meetings.
How do the total ischaemia times in the study compare to the findings of Subban et al.?
The mean total ischaemia time in the study was 412 minutes, which is much longer than the median total ischaemia time reported by Subban et al. (275 minutes).
What initiative in the Indian healthcare system is mentioned as having a profound effect on STEMI care, according to the study?
The Arogyasree, an Andhra Pradesh state government social insurance programme for people below the poverty line, is mentioned as having a profound effect on STEMI care.
What is the significance of the delay in presentation to a PCI-capable hospital, and how does it impact total ischaemia time in STEMI patients?

The delay in presentation to a PCI-capable hospital is significant as it contributes to a prolonged total ischaemia time. In STEMI patients, minimizing the total ischaemia time is essential for reducing morbidity and mortality. The pre-hospital delay and the time taken for financial decisions and referrals to local hospitals contribute to a greater total ischaemia time.
